data.name: SwampRabbitFunFact.Text
data.value: Swamp Rabbits are very good at swimming. When they are being chased by a predator, they oftentimes jump into a nearby body of water and swim away. In 1979, there was a well-publicized incident where a couple of hounds were chasing a swamp rabbit and the rabbit jumped in the water, swimming up to then-President Jimmy Carter's fishing boat. Carter shooed the rabbit away by splashing water with a paddle. This was in Georgia.

data.name: DesertCottontailHabitatTextBox.Text
data.value: Desert Cottontails inhabit the desert regions of western United States and Mexico, but they can also be found in less dry areas such as pinyon-juniper forests. States: Nebraska, Kansas, Wyoming, Nevada, North Dakota, Texas, California, New Mexico, South Dakota, Oklahoma, Colorado, Utah, Arizona, Montana, Baja California. Biomes: Desert and Xeric Shrublands, Temperate coniferous forest, Temperate grasslands, Tropical dry forest.

data.name: MarshRabbitHabitatTextBox.Text
data.value: Marsh Rabbits live in the South eastern United States and live close to water. States: Virginia, Alabama, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida. Biomes: Flooded grasslands and savannas , Mangrove, Tropical moist forests

data.name: MarshRabbitDietTextBox.Text
data.value: Diet: herbivorous. Typically, they feed on leaves and bulbs of marsh plants including cattails, brushes, and grasses. They can also feed on other aquatic or marsh plants such as centella, greenbrier vine, marsh pennywort, water hyacinth, wild potato, and amaryllis.

data.name: MarshRabbitPredators.Text
data.value: Predators: Birds of prey such as the great horned owl and northern harrier or marsh hawk are the major predators of the rabbits. Other predators include alligators, snakes, bobcats, foxes, and coyotes.

data.name: NewEnglandCottontailHabitat.Text
data.value: Lives in US and Canada. States: New York, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Vermont, QuébecBiomes: The New England cottontail is a habitat specialist. It does well in early successional forest which are forests that are less than 25 years old, with a dense understory of thick, tangled vegetation, preferably of blueberry or mountain laurel. These forests matured into closed-canopy stands and the shrub layer began to thin in the 1960s, and as a result, the New England cottontail habit declined.

data.name: NewEnglandCottontailDiet.Text
data.value: Diet: New England cottontails are herbivores and their diet varies based on the season and local forage opportunities. In the spring and summer, they primarily eat herbaceous plants (including leaves, stems, wood, bark, flowers, fruits, and seeds) from grasses and forbs. Beginning in the fall and continuing into the winter, New England cottontails consume mostly woody plants.

data.name: NewEnglandCottontailPredators.Text
data.value: Known predators of New England cottontails include weasels, domestic cats, red foxes, fishers, birds of prey, coyotes, and bobcats. Past predators may have included gray wolves, eastern cougars, wolverines, and the Canada lynx.

data.name: NewEnglandCottontailSadFact.Text
data.value: I lied. It's not a fun fact, but rather, a sad one. Muahahahaha. New England Cottontails are vulnerable to extinction due to loss of habitat, competition with Eastern Cottontails, and because they keep crossbreeding with the eastern cottontails.

data.name: SwampRabbitDiet.Text
data.value: Diet: Swamp rabbits are herbivorous; they eat a variety of foraged plants, including grasses, sedges, shrubs, tree bark seedlings, and twigs. They feed mainly at night but rain showers often cause them to feed during the daytime. A study has found that the preferred foods of Swamp Rabbits are savannah panicgrass, false nettle, dewberry and greenbrier.
